subject: Nutrition
title: Casimir Funk and the Vital Amines
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Casimir Funk and the Vital Amines.

hook.text: A Polish biochemist coined a word in 1912 that would reshape how the world thinks about food.

buildup.text: Casimir Funk studied beriberi, a deadly nerve disease that swept through Asian rice-eating populations.

discovery.text: He found that something in rice husksâ€”removed during polishingâ€”prevented the disease entirely.

twist.text: Funk believed all these vital substances were amines. He was wrong about the chemistry but right about the idea.

climax.text: His term 'vitamine' launched a revolution. Within decades, deficiency diseases became preventable.

punchline.text: One wrong name sparked the right revolution.
